awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Human cultural and ecological influences on foraging and social relationships in primates
awd_abstract_narration:
To fully understand how humans impact the environment and influence species change, it is necessary to apply a holistic perspective that views humans as members of an ecological community and recognize that human impacts on the environment are intimately tied to cultural beliefs. In this project, the researchers examine how human attitudes and behavior influence foraging and social relationships of chacma baboons that range through a mixed-use landscape that has been shaped by human culture. People's attitudes towards and interactions with the environment and animals are formed by a combination of factors, including personal experience, demographic context, and cultural knowledge transmission (e.g., parent to child). Variation in attitudes among different people can either promote conflict or facilitate existence with the baboons. When humans alter the environment, they impact food availability and predation risk for baboons. The impact of predation risk on nonhuman primate sociality, particularly risk stemming from human ecological activities and cultural beliefs, could have significant consequences for baboon relationship quality, reproduction, and survival. This research will support primate conservation efforts and student mentoring and training. 
 
This project uses an integrative methodology including ethnographic interview techniques, phenological assessment, and baboon behavioral observations to examine the influence of human attitudes and behavior on chacma baboon (Papio hamadryas ursinus) predator sensitive foraging and social relationships. Results from this research will inform our understanding of community ecology by providing data on the complex interactions between humans and nonhuman primates and provide insight into how people and nonhuman primates mutually influence each other's social and ecological landscapes. The broader impacts of this research will result in new collaborations, research methodology training and mentoring for students and collaborators, and scientific data to support conservation and management of human-baboon interactions.

por.por_cntn:
In the last decade, niche construction has been recognized as an important, non-genetic component of evolutionary inheritance. The theory posits that by altering their environment, organisms create evolutionary feedback mechanisms that impact selective pressures that act on the organism, sympatric species, and future generations of both. Humans are prolific niche constructors, altering both ecological and social environments to develop and inhabit almost every habitat type of earth through the use of generationally transmitted knowledge and tools. Currently, human niche construction is occurring more rapidly and on a larger global scale than at any point during our evolution – and resulting in the naming of a new geological epoch, the Anthropocene to emphasize how human activities like deforestation, agriculture, fossil fuel combustion are leading forces on climate change, landscape, and species survival or extinction. Humans and nonhuman primates share a long temporal and wide spatial overlap, and niche construction has been suggested as an important theoretical framework to test hypotheses stemming from the interface of the primate community. The ethnoprimatological approach focuses on the biological, cultural, and ecological interconnections between primate communities, including humans.

This on-going research, partially funded by the National Science Foundation, examines how human niche construction impacts foraging and sociality of chacma baboons (Papio hamadryas ursinus) in Hemel-en-Aarde Valley, Western Cape, South Africa. In Western Cape, baboons range through a habitat shaped by humans, wherein fragments of endemic vegetation (fynbos) are embedded in a mixed-used landscape, including commercial agricultural and human residences. People impact the habitat, altering food availability and predation risk for baboons. Baboons encounter a variety of people with differing attitudes that facilitate coexistence or promote conflict with people. Using an ethnoprimatological approach, this research tests questions that seek to uncover the synergistic role that inter-generational, culturally transmitted attitudes and changing ecological conditions have on patterns of foraging behavior and social relationships among baboons.

The project relies on an integrative and exhaustive methodological toolkit, including assessing the mosaic, anthropogenic landscape (endemic fynbos, exotic tree species [pine, eucalyptus, and acacia], vineyards, and agricultural and horticultural plots planted with olives and quinces), measuring the behavior of the baboons living there, and conducting ethnographic interviews with local residents and farmers. Ecological transects are checked monthly to monitor changes in phenological stage, food availability, and habitat transformation (both habitat regeneration and destruction). We habituated a troop of free-ranging baboons and identified all adult individuals including five adult males, 20 adult females, and four subadult males (troop composition has changed over the study period and currently includes two adult males, 18 adult females, and two subadult males). Total home range size is approximately 26 square kilometers. At present, we have conducted 40 interviews for Phase One and are preparing materials for Phase 2 interviews with adults and children.

This research tests the utility of a controversial theory, niche construction, for our understanding of primate-human interactions and will contribute to a broader, more dynamic understanding of community ecology and provide a new perspective to the traditional discussion of ecological and social niches. This research will also increase our understanding of inter-generational cultural transmission in humans by explicitly examining ecological knowledge and attitudes between parents and children, an underrepresented study population. The broader impacts of this study will benefit local, national, and international stakeholders through public and academic engagement with people of all ages and education levels. In addition, the project increase participation and training of women in scientific research, including the co-PI and three research assistants. The products of this research will include a dissertation, peer-reviewed publications, and presentations to national and international professional conference audiences. Finally, this research will provide scientific data to develop wildlife management strategies to positively support both people and baboons.
